title: Has your face ever gone numb on a plane? It's all due to pressure build up
text:

Have you ever boarded a plane feeling completely normal only for a sharp, numbing pain to spread over part of your face while in flight?
Though it sounds like the beginning of a terrifying sci-fi film, this partial facial numbness - or 'unilateral facial paralysis,' as it's known - is actually far more common than you might think.
And the good news is, there's no reason to panic if such an incident occurs. It turns out that this temporary facial numbness is actually do to a pressurised build up in the middle ear.
According to recent research, symptoms of such temporary facial paralysis usually resolve spontaneously
An article in the October 2012 issue of The Journal of Laryngology & Otology examined three cases of 'recurrent, unilateral facial palsy associated with air travel'.

Share this article Share 411 shares According to their research, the symptoms resolved spontaneously in all cases, though two patients received ventilation tube insertion to prevent further recurrence.
In the end, the doctors found that such a phenomenon is due to 'eustachian tube dysfunction' - or what amounts to increased pressure within the middle ear.
This then leads to neuropraxia, or temporary loss of motor and sensory function, of the facial nerve.
While many occurrences of this go widely unreported by flyers, if this does sound like something you've experienced, it may be worth investing in a decongestant pre-flight.
Dr. Arthur Wu, a sinus specialist at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, told Road Warrior Voices that taking oral and topical decongestants, such as Sudafed, prior to takeoff may help to open up your nasal passages.
Partial facial numbness that occurs during flight is actually far more common than one might think - and, thankfully, not permanent
